body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the total number of positive integers that can be formed using the digits "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,2,3,4,3,2,1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" when the odd digits are in odd place?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here are the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" possible odd places of the seven digit number"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 _ 3 _ 3 _ 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 _ 3 _ 1 _ 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 _ 1 _ 3 _ 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3 _ 1 _ 1 _ 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3 _ 1 _ 3 _ 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3_ 3 _ 1 _ 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here are the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" possible combinations of even places for "},{"type":"text","text":"every","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" combination above of odd places"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" _ 2 _ 4 _ 2 _ "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" _ 2 _ 2 _ 4 _ "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" _ 4 _ 2 _ 2 _ "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Giving us "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3*6 = \boxed{18}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" total possibilities."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Two third's divided by one over twenty four ..
If we're dividing we used to reciprocal the divisor and change the operation into multiplication and it will be.. two third's times twenty four over one 
2 * 24 = 48 
3 * 1 = 3 
48/3 = 16"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Thanks for using words to explain what you are doing. It makes it easier to understand the solution, especially for someone who couldn't do it.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First of all  make the denominator same of the two fractions,2/3*8/8=16/24. we have to add 16 times 1/24 to get 16/24. 
1/24+1/24+1/24+1/4........1/24=16/24=2/3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the no. of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{24}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"'s in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{2}{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be x."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now,   "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x\times \frac{1}{24} = \frac{2}{3}  \implies   x=\frac{2}{3}\times 24  \implies x=\boxed{16}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let x be the number of 1/24's in 2/3.
Then x * 1/24=2/3.
x=16."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It is possible to form an equation with the digits 1, 2, 3 and 4 using 2 operations:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1=2+3-4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Your task is to form another equation using the same digits in the same order.  Apart from the equals sign,  is it possible to use just one operation? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Details","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You are free to change the position of the equals sign."}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I do not generally believe digit concatenation may be used. Instead, my first sight is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1-2 = 3-4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
